text:
S.H.

WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN FARMERS EAT?

A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name: James Cooper
Address: West Bend
Birthplace: England

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1904
Where did you set up housekeeping? SE 18, Tp 28, R 12 W3
Where had you been living before that? (year) Manifort, England
For how many people did you prepare meals? (just myself really, mother 2 or 3)
How far was it to your nearest store? 35 miles (by foot)
How often could a visit be made to the store? (not often, but most weeks a neighbor would be going)
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
(dried fruits, baking powder, eggs, sugar, salt, flour, syrup, yeast cakes, brown sugar, jam—wouldn't make it without these)

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? "North Star"
Milled by Levi Beck, Yorkton
In what quantities did you buy it? 98 lb. bags, or two or three at a time
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $2.05
How much did you use graham flour? no
Whole wheat flour? no
Was flour milled locally? yes
How far away? 60 mi., what year? (from beginning)
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? 80¢
What other grain products did you use?
Cornmeal? no
Whole wheat? no
Farina? no
Other?

Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? yes (after about 1909)
How did you grind it? (using a chopper—putting it through 2 or 3 times)
James Cooper
West Bend, 3204

1. INTERVIEWER: Are you married?
   JAMES COOPER: Yes.

2. FLOUR: What brand of flour did you buy in the last six months?
   JAMES COOPER: Smith's Best in Yankton.

3. In what quantity did you buy it?
   JAMES COOPER: 50 pounds.

4. How much did you pay per pound?
   JAMES COOPER: $2.45.

5. Did you buy any other flour products?
   JAMES COOPER: No.

6. Did you grind your own wheat or purchase pre-ground flour?
   JAMES COOPER: I purchased pre-ground flour.

7. For how much did you grind your own wheat?
   JAMES COOPER: $8.00.

8. Did you grind your own wheat for personal use?
   JAMES COOPER: Yes.

9. For how much did you grind your own wheat?
   JAMES COOPER: $8.00.
I backed for 20 years a woman's report would be slightly different. Sometimes two of us doubled up for a time and lived together.

Sheho was our nearest town and an ox team the means of getting there. I did not go often, but could usually send in with one of the neighbors about once a week if necessary.

In the winter of 1904-05 a country store was opened by H.A. Wall about a mile S.W. of here. He carried a stock of almost everything we needed, which he had freighted out from Sheho, for which he paid $6 per cwt.

Mills were opened nearer, later, Foam Lake, I think.

I homesteaded here in 1903 and was one of the first in this township. Before that the only inhabitants had been the small ranchers who came here in the early '80s, a Frenchman M. Carion had this township to himself; the ranches were located 8 or 10 miles apart, but in some places they were grouped 3 or 4 fairly close together. These were the first pioneers. When the homesteaders came in some of the ranchers moved out and others took homesteads and changed their methods. Mr. B Carion, son of the old man, still lives in farming.

The homesteads were soon all taken and we had plenty of neighbors by the end of 1904. English, Scotch, Irish, Welsh, Scandinavian, German, American, Canadian and a little later a lot of Ukrainian and Polish. By 1906 we had schools. The railway was extended to Foam Lake in 1907-8 and the C.N.R. came only 14 miles South of us in 1908.
I reached for 20 years a woman's report would be
difficult. Sometimes two or three up for a
time and land together.

She was our nearest farm and on our own
neighbourhood. But could usually find
something there. I did not go off, but could usually find
with one of the neighbours about once a week by necessity.

In the winter of 1945-46 a country store was opened by
Mr. A. Will about a mile southwest. He carried a stock of
almost everything needed which he had freighted over
from Chicago, for which he paid $10 per cart.

Mill was opened around 1910-11, and a small one at Millburn about 1915 or
later.

I homesteaded here in 1903 and was one of the first
in the Township. Before that the only inhabitants had
been the overall ranchers who came here in the early '80s,
a Frenchman M. Bannier had thin township (Chimney), etc.
ranches were located 8 or 10 miles apart, but in some
places they were spaced 3 or 4 fairly close together. These
were the first pioneers. When the homesteaders came in
waves of the ranchers moved out and others took
over. The ranches and changed their methods. Mr. Bannier
from Canada and changed his name.

The homesteaders were soon all taken and we had plenty
of immigrants by the end of 1904. English, Scotch, Irish, Welsh,
German, American, Canadian and Polish. By 1906 we had
later a lot of Ukrainian and Polish. The railway was completed to town in 1907-8
and the C.N.R. came only 14 miles south of us in 1908.
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 100 lb. bags ($1.00 or $7.00) only the $1.00 bags.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? $2.50.

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Brown and Edwardsburg.

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 10 lbs.

At what price? $0.60.

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? We didn't have a ranch, so we bought from a nearby dairy that was good enough.

Butter? From a neighbor.

Eggs? Same.

That was the price of butter? $1.50.

Did you pack eggs for inter? No.

Did you make butter? No.

Did you make cheese? No.

What kind of cheese?

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? We either butchered our own or bought from neighbors who had a herd.

How did you get fresh meat? Sometimes when we went to town.

How often did you get fresh meat? Not often.

How did you preserve meat? In brine.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? No.

If so what year was it organized?

Did you use game? Yes.

What kinds? Ducks, pheasant, chickens.

For how long? 3-4 years.

What part did fish play in the family diet? A little canned salmon in summer and some frozen white fish in winter, or.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Frozen.

Kinds? We got them from the creek and we were able to open some.
In what quantity how much milk was purchased? (100 lb. bags $16.00 each, 50 lb. bags $8.00 each)

What was the price for a ten pound sack of cheese? (Cheese $1.25 per lb.)

That also of this or similar kind? (Price?)

At what price?

Did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? (Yes, I did not.)

When a neighborhood of farmers... (Price?)

That was then what? (Price?)

Did you pack eggs for yourself? (Yes)

Did you make butter? (Yes)

What kind of cheese?

What was your main supply in the past? (Price?)

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? (Yes)

If so what year was it organized? (Price?)

Did you use names? (Yes)

For how long? (Price?)

That part of the ring play in the family? (Price?)

And some... (Price?)

Was the dish truly owned by anyone? (Price?)

Was it... (Price?)

And was it... (Price?)

And was it... (Price?)
6. BEVERAGES

What kind of tea did you buy? Red Rose Royal Shield
At what price? 35¢ to 40¢

What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) Ground
Price? 30¢ to 40¢

What other beverages were used? Vinegar, sugar, soda

7. VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping?
50¢

Could you get potatoes at the store? No

If not, where from? McLean, who had raised them for 20 years.

What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of:
Potatoes 1904, Cabbage 1906, Carrots 1906, Onions 1906

Turnips 1906, Beets 1906

In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? 10 or 20 lbs

How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? Box

What weight? 25 lbs

How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? ...

What was the price of prunes? about 12¢

What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, peaches, apricots, peaches, raisins, currants or others)? A settler from Ontario brought a number of bags of dried apples, they were cut into pieces and dried over the kitchen stove or in the sun, he sold them at 5¢ each

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? ...

peas? ... corn? ... beans? ... Saskatoons? ...

other foods? ...

What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? After I was married in 1923

What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? ...

What year did you first preserve meat by canning? ...

Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? Yes

To what extent? Throughout the summer

Did you make your own vinegar? A few times
6. Buy what kind of tea did you buy? Red Rose, Black Tea, etc.

7. What kind of coffee did you buy? (house or ground) (ground)

8. What other beverages did you buy?

9. What was the price of potatoes at the store?

10. Can you give locations at the store?

11. If not, where from?

12. This year did you grow your own supply for two weeks of:

13. Turnips (5¢/lb.)

14. In what quantities did you buy while new beans?

15. How did you buy prunes? (in bulk or by the box)?

16. What was the price of prunes?

17. What other dried fruits did you use in the last three days?

18. In the early years did you purchase any fresh or dried peas?

19. Other foods?

20. What year did you first preserve fruits by canning?

21. What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning?

22. Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying?

23. To what extent?

24. Did you make your own vinegar?

10. BAKING

What type of yeast did you use? Dry Royal Yeast Cakes

Did you make yeast for your own use? No

Using starter? No

Using hops? No

Salt rising? No

Did you buy baking powder? Yes

Baking soda?

Cream of tartar?

Did you make your own baking powder? No

   - What type of yeast did you use?

   - Using active?
   - Salt rising?

12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (Well, river, slough, dugout) [Handwritten: Slough]

How far was this water from your home? 30 ft.

How was it brought to the house? (Pail, barrel, tank) [Handwritten: Pail]

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible. I dug a well in 1904 and others later. Had our bond 175 ft deep in 1910 and another 79 ft in 1915 put in first pump in 1915. Bond another well in 1932 which is still used for drinking. 150 yards from house, we carry in pails. Drilled well 130 ft in 1959 but not good to drink.
There was no water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, stream, dugout). 

If so, how did you get your water? 

How far was this water from your house? 

Was it brought to the house? (pail, barrel, tank) 

First started homesteading, living in tent house possible. 

In 1915 first pump up - 175 deep - 1910 and another well in '32 which was drilled. 

Still used for drinking 150 yards from house, in spring - fairly drilled until 1909 but not good to drink.
13. SOAP

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? ...bought...

If you made your own, did you use lye? ...wood ashes?

What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer handle? Royal Crown, Fatal Naphtha

6 bars 25¢

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? ...wood...

Where did you get your fuel? ...from own wood lot by hand...

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

First used sawed and split by hand but about 1911 gasoline driven buggies came in and later splitters. Some now use coal and there are a few oil burners, but wood is still the main and most satisfactory fuel.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates) ...no...

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates) ...no, but outdoor bake ovens were commonly used by the Mormons...

By whom was your first cook stove made? ...grandma...

What year was it purchased? ...1904... Price? ...$5 second-hand...

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade) ...iron, tin, enamel...

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other) ...

When did you first see enamel ware? ...

Aluminum? ...1907-8...
13. Did you buy laundry soap or make your own?
If you did, what kind? Did you use it?

14. Fuel:
What fuel did you use in your home last winter?

15. Methods of cooking and types of utensils:
For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the cellar?
Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates)
By whom was your first cook stove used?
What type of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homestead)

Price? $15.00

Year? 1904

Fuel? Anthracite coal

Year? 1907-08

Aluminum?
16. **WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS**

mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (five dates where possible).

Apples came from Ontario in barrels until about 1915 then we got BC boxes which were much higher priced and didn't hold enough water they wrapped them which added to the cost and was not beneficial. Sometimes we got apples in bulk in a box car.

Exported peaches were sold by the 25 lb box for $2.75 which was much better than the modern little cellophane wrapped packages.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g. winter or summer.

**Breakfast**
- Oatmeal porridge
- Fried bacon
- Bread, butter, syrup

**Dinner**
- Fried or broiled bacon
- Potatoes, steamed dried peaches
- Bread, butter

**Supper**
- Same as dinner
- Other vegetables when in season
- In winter beef took the place of pork or bacon with fish sometimes and beans as an extra vegetable.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Eastern Canada?

Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

In 1904 while living with W. Littlejohn we prepared Christmas dinner. Roast beef, brown gravy, potatoes, beans, & a meat pudding dinner. When it was nearly ready Mr. Johnson came with someone in it. When he was nearly ready, Mr. Johnson came along with a load of effects moving to their homestead. We all thought they had dinner with us fortunately there was enough to go round.

In 1904 George Wright gave a bachelor Christmas dinner for the homesteaders in this section. W. Littlejohn was away but Mr. Moore joined them. George was quite a cook he gave us roast beef and real pie (apple). We went to a dinner at night at Mrs. Butten's on First St.

19. Have you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

No
15. **HAPPINESS AND OPPORTUNITIES**

   Plant an orchard which you shall in due time harvest and enjoy (give dates here possible).

   *Apples came from Butten's house with us about 1913.*

   We got 13 bushels which were a higher grade and best kept.

   *Note: They were wrapped in waxed paper and no leaching took place.*

   *We got 25 lbs. for $2.75 which was excellent produce.*

   *Then the modern little apple tree will produce much better than the old apple tree.*

16. Give a capital dinner party (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the children.

   *Your family must come over. Give the roast and list the number of guests invited.*

   *With both eyes on the clock, it takes the appearance to mouth, especially if numerous.*

   *Breakfast—continental—fried bacon, bread, butter, eggs*

   *Dinner—fried or baked bacon potatoes, steamed vegetables*

   *Supper—steak, baked potatoes, bread, butter*

   *Dinner—other things like when in war*

   *Supper—steak, baked potatoes, bread, butter*

   *In winter—beef, pork or bacon with fresh*

   *Some times and brown sauce on extra nights*

17. What do you serve your first Christmas dinner in Eastern Canada?

   *Appreciate to area at that time.*

   *Give the menu. List those present, incl. their ages.*

   *Jan. 1906 while looking out west they had prepared Christmas dinner meal but brown gravy was not ready. E.M. & Agnes came along with a load of flour. Fortunately the weather was fine and the dinner was eaten by all. Mrs. Murray & Judy for 80 cents per person. This evening we dined quickly and had a good time.*

   *On Jan. 24th we started back to give details.*
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

No very great differences, but families are generally smaller and visiting is not as common.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homogrown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

We have not yet. The last three or four years it has become quite common for even farmers to buy all their bread and even cakes and cookies. But there are still a lot who do their own baking. There is also a lot of bologna used now that was never seen before the middle thirties.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Eastern Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. [Use back of page if more space is needed].

It seems very difficult now to buy anything in bulk, the merchants seem afraid to stock more of any item, than would do a good sized family for two decent meals. Most foods will improve with keeping for a time in a good basement, and then would be a great saving in cost besides the convenience of always having a supply on hand.

The old laundry soaps seem to have almost disappeared, the new powders are probably very good when each is used for the right purpose, but when used indiscriminately sometimes don't work so well.

Cold storage locker plants are coming to be used a lot but have hardly yet reached perfection, either in accessibility
No very great difference, but families are generally smaller and winters not so long.

When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homesteading and home prepared foods? (Give an early date if possible.)

We haven't yet. The last three or four years we have become quite dependent on farmers. But they all their bread and even cakes and cookies. They do still make their own baking flour.

There is also a lot of cottage cheese that was made before the middle thirties.

Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and gas for your family in other than pioneer days in Eastern Canada.

Include types of food bought, above quality, methods of merchandising, etc., prices, etc.

It seems very difficult now to buy anything in bulk at the merchants' store of which to stock more of our own. We would do a good sized family for two decent meals. Most foods will be purchased for a tin in good season, and then would be a great comfort in case of sickness. I always have a supply on hand.

The old laundry soap was probably very good when used in wash for a while, but when used immediately sometimes does not work so well.

Cold storage locker plants are coming to be used a lot.

But have hardly yet reached perfection, either accessibility.
or cost of the service. With all weather roads to take us to them, and lower cost for the service which might result from more people using them, they might bring about a great change for the better in our way of living especially in the summer time.
or cost of the service. With all weather roads to take us to them, and lower cost for the service which might result from more people using them, they might bring about a great change for the better in our way of living especially in the summer time.
